On solutions of the generalized bi-axially symmetric Helmholtz equation generated by integral operators
By R,  P,  Gilbert ^) and H.  C.  Howard ^) at College Park,  Maryland
I.  Introduction
In this page we shall use Bergman ’ s integral operator method [ 1—6 ] to investigate solutions of the partial differential equation
...  2u du.  2v 5u.  ^ _
lï ^ + - v + iriF + T ^ + '^“““'
We shall refer to this equation as the generalized bi-axially symmetric Helm holtz equation ( GBSHE ), following Weinstein [ 28—31 ] who first considered frac tional-dimensional space in potential theory.  One is led to consider this equation initially by seeking “ monochromatic ” solutions U ( X,  Y,  t ) = Ui ( X,  Y ) of the ( m + n == { 2ju I ) + ( 2v + l ))- dimensional wave equation

which depend solely on the variables X ^ = { xl -{-••• + xl ^), 5 ^^ = ( 2 /? + * * ’ + ÿ ») • Henrici has studied ( 1.  1 ) in [ 19 ], and [ 21 ]; the particular case / и = 0 has recently been studied by Gilbert and Howard [ 17 ] while the case к = ju = 0 has been the object of many investigations by Weinstein [ 28—31 ], Vekua [ 26 ], Henrici [ 19—22 ], Erdélyi [ 9 ], Gilbert [ 11—16 ], Mackie [ 23 ], and Ranger [ 25 ].
Here further properties of solutions to ( 1.  1 ) with k > 0 will be investigated by using Bergman ’ s operator method [ 1 ]. In particular,  information concerning the location of singularities and the growth of solutions will be obtained. 
II.  Integral Operators Generating Solutions to the OBSHE
We shall just consider those solutions of the GBSHE which are of class in some neighborhood of the origin and even in x and in y.  In this case we must have,  for u { x ^ y ) a solution,  that
